source.raw_text:
The Wheelbarrow Carry (pushing) heavily engages the chest (pectorals), shoulders (deltoids), triceps, and core (abdominals) for stability and force, while also working forearms, glutes, and lower back for endurance and balance; it's a compound movement pattern that emphasizes pushing strength, shoulder stability, and anti-extension core control, with significant grip and wrist strength demand as the load increases. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  
This video demonstrates how to perform the wheelbarrow carry exercise: 
Muscles Worked (Primary & Secondary) 

• Primary Movers (Pushing & Stabilizing): 

    • Pectorals (Chest): Pushing the handles forward and stabilizing the upper body. 
    • Deltoids (Shoulders): Lifting and controlling arm movements. 
    • Triceps: Extending the elbows to push. 
    • Core (Abs, Obliques, Lower Back): Maintaining a straight, stable torso, resisting flexion and lateral movement. 

• Stabilizers & Synergists: 

    • Forearms & Wrists: Grip strength, wrist stability. 
    • Glutes & Hamstrings: Stabilizing the legs and hips. [1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8]  

Movement Patterns & Benefits 

• Anti-Extension Core Work: Resisting the body's tendency to sink into spinal extension (arching the back). 
• Bilateral Coordination: Both arms work together, requiring coordinated effort. 
• Proprioception: Enhances body awareness and balance. 
• Shoulder Stability: Demands strong shoulder girdle control. 
• Grip & Forearm Endurance: Carrying heavy loads significantly challenges grip strength. 
• Dynamic Stability: Obliques work to prevent side-to-side swaying as you walk. [1, 2, 5, 9, 10]  

Key Takeaway 
It's a full-body challenge that builds pushing power, core strength, and endurance, acting as a functional exercise that strengthens the entire kinetic chain from hands to hips. [5, 9]
